div.p: 1. VI. Friday.

I resumed and finished the preparation of my Administration account, as far as I have proceeded in the settlement of my Son’s Estate— And I received and answered another Letter from my Son Charles, concerning the granite quarries at Quincy— Borland the Carpenter was here with a Bill of Estimates for the repairs of the House in the Pennsylvania Avenue which I directed him to make— I walked round the Capitol Hill before dinner, and after dinner I walked to Mr Frye’s; and left with him the minute respecting the distribution of the property of Thomas J. Hellen— He told me Mr Walter Smith at Georgetown had agreed to keep at his Store the Cask of Madeira Wine that he imported for me—to be bottled in the course of the Summer— I sat in conversation at Mr. Frye’s, till a flash of Lightning warned me that a thunder-gust was coming up— I hastened home, but before I reached the house, had the heaviest of the shower over my head— Mary was so much recovered as to come down to dinner— I wasted my time—

div.p: 2. V:30. Saturday.

There is an erosion upon Time which I never can arrest. I intended to have taken my account to the Orphan’s Court this morning; but two O’Clock came, and although I had done nothing, I was yet in my chamber. I took my four Orations and three Reports composed since 1831. to the Book-binders, and left them there to be bound in a Volume— I had one Volume of my compositions bound before The Silesian Letters and the Lectures on Rhetoric and Oratory form three other Volumes.— A complete collection of what I have printed would form one, or two volumes more— I am collecting other pamphlets to be bound.— They accumulate excessively upon my hands, and the proportion of them that deserve to be preserved is not very great. The selection is no easy, and a very tiresome task. I called at the fourth Auditor’s Office, and saw Robert Johnson, a Clerk there, and Treasurer of the Columbian College to enquire respecting the interest due upon their bond to me, of which there are nearly two years due— He said he hoped to receive funds from Mr Rice very soon but had none at present— I told him that I was going in a few days to leave the City for the Summer, and must before my departure discharge certain debts— If I could not receive the interest due to me from the College I should be obliged to borrow money and pay interest upon it; to indemnify me for which I must claim interest upon the arrears due more than a year from the college— He said this was reasonable and he believed the Trustees of the College would be willing to pay it— I said I should write to him on the subject next week— I then called at M. A. Giusta’s, and gave him directions for bottling my Cask of wine; at Walter Smith’s Store, in Georgetown, about the first of August, which he promised— He offered me a loan of one thousand dollars for a year at 5 per cent interest— Walked round the Capitol Hill— Directed Borland to make the repairs required by Mrs Wolfenden at the House on Pennsylvania Avenue— Dr Kuhl was here also and at his solicitation I authorised him to make repairs to the amount of . . . dollars in the Shop which he is to occupy at 12 1/2 dollars a month from this day— A man by the name of Edwards was here this afternoon with Riggles and engaged the house next to Carbery’s at 5 dollars a
month for the present— Mr Boyle came to enquire what was the cost of the granite steps at the House in F. Street which my Son John procured at Quincy and had brought round here, but I was not able to tell him— He said he wanted steps for the entrance to his own house, and had concluded to procure them of the Quincy granite. He had written to Boston to enquire the price of procuring it, but had not received an entirely satisfactory answer— I answered this Evening two Letters accepting the election of honorary member of Literary Societies in the La Fayette College at Easton Pennsylvania, and at the University of Vermont at Burlington.
3. V:30. Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church, and heard a Stranger from Titus 3.8. “This is a faithful saying, and these things I will that thou affirm constantly, that they which have believed in God might be careful to maintain good works. These things are good and profitable unto men.” There was not that impressiveness in the discourse which could leave the memory of it upon my mind— He gave notice after the Sermon that the Presbytery had directed the distribution among the members of the Society of a number of Copies of Doddridges Rise and progress, and of Baxter’s Saint’s rest, and that the person who should preach to them this afternoon, would make further observations to them on the subject— Mrs Frye dined with us— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Service for the second Sunday after Easter, and preached from Colossians 3.2. [“]Set your affections on things above, not on things on the earth”—and the following verses— After Church Mrs Adams walked with Mrs Frye to their Sister Smith’s, and sometime after, Mr and Mrs Smith came here— I walked home with them, and found Mrs. Adams and Mrs Frye there— I walked home again with Mrs Adams— I read the 27th. Sermon of Dr Bancroft’s Volume, on the doctrine of universal restoration, against which he pronounces a decisive opinion—and the 28th. on the annihilation of the incorrigibly wicked— He strongly favors this; but all speculation upon the future existence of the Soul is unsatisfactory— St. Paul expressly affirms that the resurrection will be corporeal—a glorious and incorruptible body— But how?— St. Paul declares whoever makes the enquiry a fool— A state of existence after this life; a state of responsibility and of retribution, is probable—how it can be unchangeable we cannot see— Christianity proves the resurrection— It announces a state of happiness exempt ever afterwards from death— Believing this we must trust the ruler with his skies—
4. V:30 Monday

My old crazy acquaintance from Fauquier County Virginia Dr Wallace called upon me, while we were at Breakfast this morning, and I found by his conversation that his eccentricities are growing upon him— His right hand was cruelly scarred from wounds not yet well healed and which he told me were caused by a wolf he had caught to keep tame. He wished to ascertain what would be the operation of his nature in a famished state— So he kept him two days without food, and having killed a lamb he had smeared his arms and his bosom with its blood, and then went to the wolf— The animal at the first moment made a desperate leap at his throat, but he warded him off with a stroke of his arm— The wolf then flew at his arm, and fastened his teeth in the fleshy
part of his arm; but with his right hand he broke off his hold, and the wolf then drove his teeth into the hand— He on his hand drove his fist down the wolf’s throat, forcing him to open his jaws, and then jammed his head to the side of wall, till he completely mastered him, and flung him off disabled— I asked him if he kept the wolf afterwards as a social inmate—he said not long— He had wanted his hide to be tanned— I asked him how his rattlesnake family were now— He said the rattlesnake was the most perfect gentleman in the world— He never made offensive War, and always gave notice of his purpose of self defence— I asked him how the Elections were going in Virginia— He said he took no interest in them, and had nothing to do with them. But that from what he heard there would be a large majority in the Legislature in favour of the Administration, and of the New-York man, Van Buren. He said he wanted to have the power to make three Laws— 1. The total abolition of Slavery throughout the world— 2. The abolition of all coercive legal process for the recovery of debts—and 3. a Law by which persons ill sorted in marriage and disagreeing might be separated— He was very declamatory upon all three points, and very intolerant of interruption— I contested only the third of his projects, which I thought would operate entirely against the woman. He told me he was going to attend a sick woman at Point comfort— His eye looks unusually wild, and he has little sanity of mind left— At the Department of State I made an exchange with Asbury Dickins the Chief Clerk, of two old Sessions pamphlet Acts of Congress for two that I wanted to make up a volume— Mr Forsythe left the City this morning for a short visit to Georgia, by the way of New-York— Mr Dickens spoke much of prospects of change in our relations with China, consequent upon the extinction of the English East-India Company, and the general opening of the China trade to the English Merchants— He said the English Merchants at Canton had got into a quarrel with the Chinese Government, and were urging their own to assume a hostile attitude, and bring the Chinese to terms by force— He thought they might succeed; but I did not— I settled the accounts of my deceased Son at W. Cox’s and P Kinchy’s, and called to ask for his account at Clagett’s— Then I took my drafted account to the Orphan’s Court, to ascertain if it was in due form— Mr Neil the Register told me that all the vouchers, whether Accounts, notes, or bonds must be authenticated under Oath of the Creditors before a Magistrate— I then called on B. O. Tayloe, and requested him to make Oath to the account which I had settled with him in January, which he readily promised— I sent him the account this Evening— There was a heavy thundergust which confined me to the house the remnant of the day.
5. V:30. Tuesday.

I was engaged in one of the most tedious and dispiriting operations in the world; that of sweeping off from my bookshelves and out of the house waggon-loads of pamphlets and old newspapers— The numbers of them that accumulate from day
to day, and from week to week are incredible— To tear them all up and use them as waste paper savours too much of the Vandal, to keep them all makes loads of lumber, and finally choaks up the house; besides adding imprudently to the danger of fire— I have now files of nearly one hundred different newspapers—and of as many periodical magazines, Reviews, and Journals of every sort and description; besides Addresses, Eulogies, Orations, Discourses, Sermons, Dissertations, Poems, and Plays without number—nine tenths of them fit for nothing but to be burnt— And yet some of them are very valuable— To select the wheat from the chaff is an excruciating task— I went to the Union Bank at Georgetown, with the three Notes that I had taken up during the winter and asked Mr English the Cashier to make the necessary affidavit before a magistrate, to obtain their allowance by the judge of the Orphan’s Court, which he promised to do— I then went to the Capitol, and proposed to Mr Follansbee, who has charge of the Public Documents, to send him a waggon load of them from my Treasures; and which he said he would very gratefully accept. I came home, and agreed with M. Antoine Giusta, to borrow a thousand dollars of him for a year at five per Cent interest; which will be necessary for me to pay off a remnant of debt here and for travelling expenses to Quincy. Johnson Hellen’s two children, a boy and a girl were here to spend the day and dined with ours— There was again a heavy thunder shower this afternoon which confined me to the house; and I had a painful tooth-ache and swollen cheek which has been three days coming on.
6. V. Wednesday

The swelling of my face and gums was at its height and began to subside— I went to the Union Bank at Georgetown where Mr English the Cashier made before a magistrate an affidavit with regard to the notes which had been signed by my Son, and which I have paid; and I took it with me— Mr Burnet the President told me he had lost almost all the peach trees in the garden he has in Georgetown, by the Winter’s frost. I paid small bills at Fischer’s, where I met Miss Delia Stewart, and Richard Derby—and at Kinchy’s— Called at the Franklin Insurance Company, for the dividend on my Stock which has been advertised; but Mr Joseph H. Bradley the Secretary informed me that the Directors had determined before paying my dividend, to call for new endorsers upon all my security notes, and he gave me a Letter that he had written to me to that effect. I told him I questioned the authority of the Directors to require new endorsers— He asked me to write to the Directors, and state to them my desire not to give further endorsers which I promised to do— I walked then to the Capitol, and promised Mr Follansbee to send him a waggon load of old documents— After I came home M. A. Giusta was here and told me he had deposited to my credit one thousand dollars at the U.S. Branch Bank; for which I gave him my note, payable within a year, upon interest at the rate of 5 per Cent a year— Mr W. S. Smith was also here; and I gave him for the use of Mr Heyward the Commissioner of the Land Office, the two maps shewing the bounds of the territory in dispute between Ohio and Michigan— Mr Heyward has been required by the President to make him a historical report on the whole subject; and Mr Heyward wishes for documents
Mr Smith said something of a new discovery which was expected to have some bearing on the question— The correction of an error in the survey from neglect of attending to the variation of the compass— This is a new device for settling the question in favour of Ohio.
7. V. Thursday.

Morning occupied in the preparation and copying of my account for the Orphan’s Court— Blake the Bookbinder sent me the volume of pamphlets of my own Orations Speeches and Reports which I had left with him for binding— The second that I have compiled, and yet very incomplete— It has suggested to me the project of forming a more complete collection— I sent to Blake seven Volumes of Niles’s Register— At the door of his shop I met Mr Heyward, the Commissioner of the General Land Office, who stopped me, and said the President had called upon him for a report of all the facts relating to this boundary controversy between Ohio and Michigan— He said he was very sorry for it because he was an Ohio man—but all that he should do would be to make a statement of facts, and he would be obliged to me for any documents I could communicate to him which might illustrate the subject— He said Coll. Howard the Commissioner was the person who had suggested the omission of the allowance for the variation of the compass, as a cause of error in drawing the boundary line; but how the variation can affect it I do not see— I took my account and vouchers to the orphans court found the judge there— He examined the account item by item, and every charge in every one of the vouchers— He admitted about half the charges, and struck out the rest, among those which he admitted were the Union Bank Notes, and M. A. Giusta’s claim, but not B. O. Tayloe’s account, though supported by his Oath— He said that for the balance of an account there must be the oath not only of the creditor, but of a disinterested witness besides. Mr Frye called upon me after dinner, and returned to me the statement respecting the distribution of Thomas J. Hellen’s property, left by him at his decease— I mentioned to him that Johnson Hellen, after objecting to settle with me as Administrator, with reference to that property; and my acquiescing, in having the settlement made entirely by Mary, he had applied through her to me, to sign the receipts for the money, which she received—and that I had signed the receipts without hesitation: at which he was surprized. He asked me whether I should not be obliged to give credit for it in my administration account. I told him I had already given it.
8. V. Friday.

Went over to Georgetown, and took William C. Greenleaf with me to a magistrate before whom he made oath to the account with B. O. Tayloe which had been made out by him from my Son’s books— He told me he was going to open a Coal and wood wharf in connection with Mr Edes; and I requested him at the proper time to procure a supply of the Pennsylvania Coal for our consumption the next winter, which he promised to do. I took the account with Mr Tayloe thus authenticated to the Orphans Court, where it was
now admitted by the Judge—and there being now admitted charges exceeding all the assets in my hands, I shall leave the rest without taking the trouble to authenticate them further— Two accounts are still to be settled, before I can bring this first account to a close—after which there will be little to be done— From the experience I have had, I should decline to pay any demand in future, till after a certificate upon it from the register that it will be admitted— This has been done in several of the cases of claims, and with this judge;—it should always be done— He is scrupulous overmuch— More than any other judge of the Orphans Courts in Maryland— His integrity however is unquestioned. I called next at the Mayor’s Office, and received from him a Deed of Square 592 under the sale for taxes in 1826— He returned me also the two Deeds from B. O. Tyler to me of 29. March 1820 and 8. Feby 1821. Tyler’s title was from the Corporation itself— But the legality of the sale being questioned by James Greenleaf, the Square was again sold for taxes in 1826. and bought in by my Son John for me— The surplus beyond the amount due for the taxes was bid up high by James Greenleaf who attended the Sale; but my title being from the Corporation, the surplus was of course payable to me. The Mayor gave me accordingly a check on the Patriotic Bank, signed by him and countersigned by the Register Hewitt, for 472:32. payable to my order and which I endorsed— He said that Mr James Greenleaf might make a suit of it in Chancery— I took the deed to the Office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court William Brent, and left it to be recorded— I went next to the Capitol, and looked at the copy of the map reported 8 March 1820 to the House of Representatives, by President Monroe, of the boundary of Ohio and Michigan, as surveyed under the act of Congress of 20. May 1812. There was no report from the Surveyor with the map; nor any thing to shew by whom the map was taken— I spoke with Mr Follansbee upon the Waggon load of Documents that I have sent him, and of those which I am still to send— I walked home, gathering some Elm and Maple seeds on the way— After dinner towards Evening I returned the visit of Governor Cass, the Secretary of War—and had about an hour of miscellaneous conversation with him— Mrs Cass and one of his daughters were there— He spoke of the news from France as flattering; and of the accounts from the border war between Ohio and Michigan; as very threatening and dangerous.— I went out and came home with rain.

div.p: 9. V:15. Saturday.

Cold North-East storm, with rain all the morning, and until near Sunset— It obliged us to kindle again all our fires; and affected my wife so that she had a fainting fit, and took to her bed. Mary was also very unwell— Before dinner I went to the General Land-Office to enquire, if there were not some explanatory documents respecting the survey of the Michigan and Ohio boundary, the map of which was reported to the House of Representatives by President Monroe in March 1820 The Commissioner of the General Land-Office, Mr Heyward was not there; but I saw the Chief Clerk
John M. Moore, and the next in order, Samuel D. King, and from them received some useful information— The General Land-Office, was established by Act of Congress of the 25th. of April 1812. and on the 5th. of May—Edward Tiffin of Ohio was appointed the first Commissioner— On the 14th. of November 1812 Josiah Meigs was appointed Surveyor General, and on the 10th. of October 1814. they exchanged places—Meigs being appointed Commissioner of the General Land Office, and Tiffin Surveyor General— On the 20th of May 1812. Congress passed an act to authorise the President of the United States to ascertain and designate certain boundaries— This act directed the surveyor general under the direction of the President, as soon as the consent of the Indians could be obtained, to cause to be surveyed the western and northern boundary of Ohio, bordering on the Territories of Indiana and Michigan, agreeably to the Act of 30. April 1802 for admitting Ohio into the Union; and to cause to be made a plat or plan of the boundary line from the Southern extreme of Lake Michigan to Lake Erie— Upon this Survey nothing was done, till 1815 when under an order from the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, the Surveyor General, employed a man named Harris, who instead of running a line according to the Acts of Congress, ran it according to the line proposed in the Constitution of the State of Ohio— This line of course was not approved—but in 1818. under a new order from the Commissioner of the Land Office, the Surveyor General employed a person named Fulton (Harris having declined, under a plea of inadequate compensation[)]— Fulton’s line is the one which was reported in March 1820, by President Monroe, to Congress— There are however several errors in this which require further clearing up— The most extraordinary circumstance of all is the wilful deviation of Harris, from the line prescribed by the Acts of Congress, to the line requested by the Constitution of Ohio.— There were shewn to me, several Letters, between the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, the Surveyor General, and the Governor of Michigan, then Mr. Cass— I deferred further enquiries till next week— I wrote a Letter to James Moorhead, with which I return to him his manuscript versification of the Psalms.
10. V.15. Sunday

Morning service—heard at the Presbyterian Church, a stranger from Hebrews 13.8. [“]Jesus Christ, the same yesterday, to day, and forever”— Afternoon, at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read prayers for the third Sunday after Easter, and preached from Psalm 145.13 “Thy kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and thy dominion endureth throughout all generations”— Remarkable, how nearly the same the substance of both the texts. Mr Hawley commented upon the four kingdoms of the prophecy of Daniel; of which this everlasting kingdom he said had taken the place— Mrs Frye and her Son were here before dinner, but did not stay. I read the 29th. and last Sermon of Dr Bancroft’s volume, on the future happiness of the righteous.— This series of Sermons upon subjects much controverted in the Christian Church appear to me very superficial. The topics are interesting in the highest degree— Scarcely any thing in the Book has left any impression upon my memory— I thirst for some new idea, upon these all important
questions— Dr Bancroft has a high reputation among our Clergy. This Book has not raised his character in my estimation— It is scarce equal to another volume on the same subjects—A Treatise of Theology, a small volume which I received in February 1832. from its author William S. Andrews, also dated at Worcester; but which I have not yet read— I took it up this day, and read the argument to prove that a future life is discoverable by reason— The singularity of this argument is that it adduces Revelation as the proof of this position— I doubted whether it was advisable for me to read further after this sample of the author’s mind. I answered a Letter from a person named Fell, at Hamilton, Madison County, New York, who wrote to enquire my opinion of the Constitutionality and propriety of the Resolution of the Senate, charging the President with a violation of the Constitution I doubted much whether I ought to answer the Letter at-all.
11. V:30 Monday.

I find the sorting and sifting of my pamphlets an endless task. I intended this time to have made thorough work of it, but have been ten days engaged upon it, and seem to be no nearer the end of my labours than when I began— I answered a Letter from Phinehas Harmon, who wrote to me some months since asking of me an autograph for a Town Lyceum at North Ashford in the County of Berkshire, Massachusetts. I wrote also to judge Hopkinson at Philadelphia, and mentioned to him my purpose to leave this City next Monday and to pass the week until Saturday at Philadelphia. Mr T. B. Johnson was here this morning, and Walter Hellen for a few minutes from Alexandria. Three or four days since I had visits from thirteen Baptist Ministers, who were here attending a religious convocations of pastors of that denomination among those were Mr Wayland the President of Brown University, and Mr Hague of Boston—the names of the others I could not retain.
12. V:15 Tuesday.

I have something like a whitlow coming at the first joint of the forefinger of my right hand, which threatens to disable me for writing— These infirmities come upon me in thick succession; warning me that it is time for me to withdraw from the world of bustling action— I have perhaps lingered upon it too long— I called this morning at the office of the Secretary of the Navy Mahlon Dickerson; but he was gone to New-York— I saw the Chief Clerk John Boyle; and made enquiries of him concerning Henry Wilson, who came to me last Summer at Quincy, to make application for him for a pension— He brought me nothing but his discharge, given him by Commodore Chauncey at Brookline, Long Island in 1830—but he thought that there would be found at the Navy Department evidence of his having been disabled in the Service— But no such evidence was found—Mr Boyle afterwards sent me back the certificate of discharge, with a note of the Evidence which would be necessary to entitle the man to a Pension. I went to the War Office, and
had some conversation with the Secretary, Cass, upon the boundary question between Ohio and Michigan— He had on his table a Report from the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, with copies of the correspondence which I had seen at that Office on Saturday— I asked him how it was possible that Edward Tiffin, Surveyor General in 1815 should have authorised the Survey of Harris who drew the line from the South bend of Lake Michigan, not as was directed by the act of Congress of 20. May 1812. due East to Lake Erie; but about E.N.E. to the North cape of Maumee Bay—that is precisely the claim of Ohio— He said Tiffin had been President of the Convention which formed the Constitution of Ohio and afterwards Governor of the State—that he was an honest man, but had mistaken the import of the act of Congress— He shewed me also Coll. Talcott’s report of his Survey; made under an act of 14 July 1832. ch. 229. Session pamphlet p. 201. with supplement in the general appropriation act of 2. March 1833. p. 46. these were documents to which I had not before given attention— Mr Cass said the prospect now was that the war would be suspended— The Commissioners of Ohio employed to run the line within the Michigan Territory having been routed—and although they themselves escaped nine men of their party were arrested, and lodged in prison in Michigan within the disputed line— The men were taken on Sunday the 26th. of April; and the Governor of Ohio cannot rescue them, but by an act of unequivocal war— Mr Cass said the Report from the Commissioner of the general Land Office, with the annexed documents would be published in a few days— I took home to Mr Fendall several books which he had lent me some years since; and called at the Office of the Register of Wills with my additional vouchers—but I had forgotten to pay Clagett’s bill which of course was not receipted. I returned to the Congress Library, all the books I had taken out except Sir Robert Filmer— At the Clerk’s Office I procured a copy of Talcott’s report, and re-examined the two plats of survey—reported by Mr Crawford to President Monroe 7. March 1820. and by Mr Monroe to Congress the next day— It is remarkable that there is nothing in those documents to shew by whom those plats were taken, but it must have been both by Harris and Fulton— I met at the Clerk’s Office Eleazar Early, who told me he was the Librarian of the House of Representatives an Office of which I knew not the existence— In the Evening I took a second walk, and made a half hour’s call at Mr W. S Smith’s—
13. V:15. Wednesday.

As the day of my departure approaches, business to be done accumulates, and I have now an additional cause of anxiety to those I have usually had before—leaving the house for the Summer, without the family to reside in it— The assortment of my papers will be left extremely imperfect and the confusion among them will be
great. After a much occupied morning, I called at the National Intelligencer Office, and found there four Volumes of Niles’s Register which had been left there 14. Septr. 1831. to be bound, but wanting a few numbers to make them complete these had never been supplied— I sent them all to Mr Blake who has the subsequent volumes; and wrote to Mr Niles for the missing numbers. Deebles afterwards came to my house and took the file of National Intelligencers from July 1831 to the end of the year 1834.— Mrs Ann Klapp came to spend a few days here with Mary— Mrs Wolfenden came to ask for more repairs upon the house which she occupies, and I gave her permission to have painting and whitewashing done ad libitum—towards Evening I went to Mr Frye’s, and returned to him two Accounts which he had lent me some months since, and proposed to him to give him a power of Attorney, to act for me, in my private business concerns during my absence to which he assented— I gave him a verbal statement of the condition of my affairs here; and promised to give him the substance of it in writing— Evening employed on my Diary, with a crippled hand— There were two Gentlemen who came here this Morning, for a contribution to pay the debt of the Unitarian Church.
14. V:15 Thursday

I went out this morning to see the condition of the Columbian Mills— I found Mr Speakman the Miller there; doing nothing—having done nothing or next to nothing the whole winter—unable to pay a cent of his rent; and likely to do nothing in future. I told him I proposed to advertise the Mills for rent the ensuing Season— He said he would come and see me on Saturday morning and perhaps make me a proposal to take the Mills for the year, but there never had been so bad a season as the last— As I returned to the City I passed by the Race grounds and met many persons going to them— I called at the Office of the Franklin Insurance Company and spoke with the Secretary Joseph H. Bradley of their dividend and of the demand of the Directors for new endorsers upon the Contingent notes— He said he had not been able to get a meeting of the Directors since my answer to his last Letter, but he would make another effort before I should go away— At the Office of the Register of Wills I took the copy of my Administration Account to which I had made Oath yesterday and which was then passed. I now returned to the Library of Congress the only book which I had not already returned and that was the Works of Sir Robert Filmer— I had retained it to read his Treatise upon the difference between a Hebrew and an English Witch; but I have not had time for that edifying perusal. At the Clerk’s Office of the House of Representatives I found two or three additional Documents upon the disputed boundary between Ohio, and Michigan; and with them the necessity for further enquiries— I found a Bill which passed the House of Representatives for a fresh Survey in May 1828—the
same bill as it was then stop’d in the Senate; and the Bill as again reported by Mr Strong in December 1828. and as it was amended and passed the House in Jany. 1829. Strong’s Report mentions Resolutions of the Legislative Council of the Territory of Michigan, and a Memorial from the Governor and Judges as having been referred to the Committee— The Resolutions were found upon the files; but the memorial was missing— Mr Smith called on me this afternoon and returned the maps I had lent to the Commissioner of the general Land Office— He said the Commissioner had sent me a copy of his Report, but I have not received it.
15. V:15. Friday.

Mr Frye was here this morning; and brought with him my tax-bill for the year 1834 and that of my deceased Son. I gave him a check for each of them, and one for the balance of my tax-bill for the year 1833. He asked me to make this payment to him, to enable him to retain as a set off a nearly equal sum due to Walter Hellen, and his mother, as interest of a debt from the Corporation of the City— I received this morning a Letter from my Nephew and namesake, who went to the Mediterranean last autumn with Captain Nicholson— It enclosed a Letter from Captain Nicholson to the Secretary of the Navy, highly approving his conduct, and recommending him for a Midshipman’s warrant— I took this Letter to the Navy Department and delivered it to Mr Boyle the Chief Clerk, who said he would ask the special attention to it of the Secretary of the Navy upon his return; but he thought he could not yet issue for my nephew a regular Midshipman’s warrant, as he had not receive an acting Midshipman’s warrant—but Captain Nicholson had been directed to receive him as a boy and to assign to him Midshipman’s duties— I applied at the fourth Auditor’s Office for Mr Robert Johnston, the Treasurer of the Columbian College, but learnt that since Mr Kendall’s translation to the Office of Postmaster General, he had also been transferred to that Department— I called upon the Secretary of War, to enquire for the Memorial of the Governor and Judges of the Territory of Michigan, missing from the files of the House of Representatives— He told me he had received it this morning from the general Land-Office— It was dated in 1818— He had also another document to which I had not adverted— A memorial from the Legislature of Ohio presented to the House of Representatives in March 1834. requesting that this Northern boundary line might be fixed. He said they had presented to Congress no less than five Memorials upon the subject, and now they thought it the simplest thing in the world to take the matter into their own hands, and run the line and assume the jurisdiction by force.— He told me that the Commissioners peace-makers, sent by the President, Rush and Howard were on their way back having effected nothing, and that the Governor of Ohio had convinced the Legislature to meet on the 8th. of June, to call upon them to provide funds, and furnish the means
to run the line, with a force adequate to overpower resistance— I said there had been some intimations that the President would remove the Governor of Michigan, to prevent an actual conflict of arms— He said the Governor of Michigan had strictly confined himself within the bounds of the Law— The President could hardly remove him for that— The Laws of the Territory had as yet proved sufficient for their own vindication. If they should not the Laws of the United States prescribed the mode in which the President must interfere— He thought the prospect very unpromising— Towards Evening I called at Genl. Macomb’s, but he was not at home, and I spent an hour with Mr Thomas B. Johnson.
16. V:15 Saturday

Mr Speakman the Miller came this morning as he had promised; but said he had not found any person in Georgetown willing to make an offer to take the Mills for the ensuing Season— They thought it was too early in the Season to ascertain what prospect there may be of doing profitable business— The harvest is said to be unpromising, and the price of flour has risen— The other Mills in this neighbourhood have been ruining all their owners, and this morning the Farmers and Mechanics Bank at Georgetown, have advertised the Sale of both Lyons’s Mills— Nourse’s has made 8 or 10 thousand dollars of debt in the year— I told Mr Speakman that I should leave a power of Attorney with Mr Frye who would advertise the Mills for rent, or agree with him upon the terms on which he might work them— I called on Mr Robert Johnston. The Treasurer of the Columbian College, at the general Post-Office, and spoke of the two years interest, due from the College to me— He said there had been no meeting of the board of Trustees since he had written to me. That he had since seen Mr Rice, who expected to recover a debt to the College of about 3000 dollars by next September— I told him I had been compelled to borrow money upon which I was paying interest, to discharge obligations from which this money due from the College would relieve me— And that I should be under the necessity of claiming interest on the arrears of the College if they should continue— He promised to obtain as soon as possible a meeting of the Trustees, and to let me know the result— I proceeded to the Capitol, and in the Clerk’s Office, obtained a copy of the Memorial from the Legislature of Ohio, to Congress, respecting the Boundary question with Michigan—presented in March 1834. I found also in the House Journal of 19 Feby 1827. another Memorial from the Legislature of the same State on the same subject referred to the Judiciary Committee, but no report; and the Memorial was not on the files— Returning home from the Capitol, I gathered under a red Maple tree on the Eastern border of the enclosure round the Capitol, a small handful of fallen seeds— The tree has borne this year very full, and the seeds are now all fallen; under the tree there were a few, which had just come up, the cotyledons being just opened— This ascertains that the seeds of the Maple like those of the Elm ripen in the Spring, and that they vegetate immediately after falling— My purpose is of making the experiment to sow these seeds, after I get home. The Season there is from three weeks to a month later than here— Our children had
for company to dine with them Thomas J. Frye, the Son and two daughters of Captain Twiggs of the Marine Corps, Mary Brent a grand-daughter of Mrs Cottringer, and Theodore Talbot— Mrs Ann Klapp who has been spending some days with Mary, went home with the children of her Sister, Mrs Twiggs.

17. V. Sunday.— I went this morning to the Presbyterian Church, but found it closed. Mr Smith not having returned from his excursion; and there being no preacher to supply his pulpit, there was no performance of religious worship there— I then went to St. John’s Church where Mrs. Adams and Mary had gone before. Mr Hawley read prayers for the fourth Sunday after Easter, and preached from Proverbs 1.5. “A wise man, will hear, and will increase learning; and a man of understanding shall attain unto wise counsels.”— He gave notice that the Bishop of the Diocese would be there next Sunday the 24th. instt. to preach and to administer to those who should desire it the ceremony of confirmation— He gave notice also of a Sunday School Union Meeting at Dr Laurie’s Church at 1/2 past 3. O’clock this afternoon, and as a consequence from this that there would be no afternoon Service at St. John’s— Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us— At half past three O’Clock I took Louisa with me, and went to Dr. Laurie’s Church to attend the Sunday School Meeting. We heard two addresses; one from a Gentleman from North-Carolina, and one from Mr Browne of Boston; but the house was much crowded; the heat was oppressive; and Louisa seemed not unlikely to faint, so that I left the House with her and came away before the Services were finished— Having no Sermons at hand, I read two or three chapters of William Sullivan’s Moral Class-Book, and particularly remarked his argument that Man is a necessary part of the inhabitancy of the globe of Earth— The idea was new to me, and appeared to deserve much consideration— I found a new trouble in my collection of old coins and medals, and finally concluded to pack them up and ship them for Quincy, with my Letter Books and Diaries. My perplexity was great, but I wrote a Power of Attorney to Mr Frye—and a Letter of Instructions, which I also copied. Mrs Adams was suddenly taken ill this evening after going to bed, and continued ill about three hours— I sent for Dr Huntt, who thought it would pass over before morning. I was up till Midnight, and then came to sleep in the upper chamber.
18. V. Monday. From Washington to Baltimore.

Mrs. Adams was so much recovered as to be up and about the house. Mr Frye came immediately after breakfast— I went with him to Mr R. S. Briscoe of the Treasury Department, who with Lund Washington, attested my power of Attorney to Nathaniel Frye, of which he then as a magistrate took the acknowledgment— I gave it with the Letter of Instructions to Mr Frye and then called at Mr Blake the Bookseller’s for his Bill, but he was not at his shop— I sent to engage a Seat in one of the Stages that were to leave the City at two O’Clock for Baltimore but received for answer that they were all full, and not a seat was to be had. All the extra Stages were at the other end of the line, having been engaged to carry persons to the races. I found it impossible to procure a Seat in any Stage to go this day. I wrote to Mr Nicholas Biddle, to announce my disappointment at being unable to reach Philadelphia, to dine with him
to-morrow as I had promised; but as a last effort I went to Smith, the livery Stable-keeper and engaged a light barouche and pair of horses to take me this night to Baltimore. He came between four and five, and asked me to take in as a fellow passenger a Mr Clark, who was anxiously wishing to get to Baltimore this Evening; to which I consented— Walter Hellen came up from Alexandria, and will stay with the Ladies till they follow me. We started in the open Barouche, just before five, and without stopping even to feed the horses, we arrived at Barnum’s hotel at Baltimore a quarter of an hour before Midnight. The house was full, and not a chamber to be had; but Captain Ballard of the Navy gave up to me his chamber for the Night, he himself having a bed made up for him in the chamber of Captain Dallas who was also there. I sat with them, in Captain Dallas’s chamber conversing upon the races, the Convention for nominating a Candidate for the succession to the Presidency, now assembling here; the state of affairs with France, and the rumours of resignation of the Secretaries Forsyth and Cass, till near two in the Morning when I retired to bed.
19. V. Tuesday. From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

At five, I arose, and after reading a page or two of Fanny Kemble (Mrs Butler)’s Journal which was on Captain Ballard’s Table I walked to the Steamboat Carroll, Captain Chaytor, which loosened from the wharf precisely at six— There were a multitude of passengers, among whom, the Secretary of War, Cass, and his two daughters—George Washington Campbell—Mr. Thomas, the President of the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road company— Another Mr Thomas Speaker of the House of Delegates of Maryland; Mr Brimmer of Boston, with four Ladies of his family—Coll. Abraham Eustis—Mr Bayard of Philadelphia. Judge Glenn and his Son: a young Englishman named Murray, a grandson of the late Earl of Dunmore—The Revd. Mr Johns of Baltimore, and a Mr Graham, but of where, I do not recollect. There were other persons who have been heretofore acquainted with me, and who knew me, but whose names I did not remember— Precisely at 11. O’Clock we landed at Frenchtown, and were a quarter of an hour in getting seated in the Railway Cars— We crossed in one hour to Newcastle, and in the Robert Morris Steamboat, Captain Jenkins— The tide was ahead, and it was half-past 3 O’Clock when I landed at the Chesnut Street wharf— There I found Mr John Sergeant, waiting for me, and he walked with me to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s, where I have promised to pass a few days— Mr Biddle had engaged company to dine with me. The party with Mrs Biddle, and their two Sons Edward and Charles, were judge Burnside, Dr Chapman Mr D. W. Coxe, Coll. W Drayton, Judge Hopkinson, Lord Powerscourt—a Polish Count Strunecki, Mr John Sergeant, Mr Robert Walsh, and Coll. Watmough. The dinner was very pleasant and social. The transition from Winter’s cold to the temperature of midsummer has been very sudden. I could scarcely find in the Steam-boats a place sufficiently cool. The Conversations of the day were idle. Lord Powerscourt made me an apology for not having called upon me last Winter at Washington— He said it had escaped his recollection— But he said nothing of having left an invitation to dinner unanswered— I told him there was no occasion for an apology, and that I hoped he would think no more about it.— From his conversation he appears to be a young man of small capacity, and of large pretensions.— A Lord of the John Bull family.
20. V. Wednesday.

Morning visit from Commodore Biddle with whom I had an hour of pleasant conversation— I wrote before Breakfast to my wife—and rode out with my kind host to the Penitentiary, but Mr Wood was not there, and then to the Girard College—the walls of which have arisen already two Stories high— The Colonnades round the building are to be of marble and of the Corinthian order— The front of the building itself is also of marble a beautiful kind of which is brought down to them upon the Railway. But the Will of Mr Girard prescribes that the three Stories shall consist each of four rooms, and each room fifty feet square— This had been found difficult of execution upon principles both of Architecture and of utility— On returning into the City near the door of the Bank we met Dr. Sutherland, who spoke to me, and appeared to be much concerned about the Presidential Convention who meet this day at Baltimore— He said they had gone there to quarrel, and that he had some thoughts of going there to see what they were about— I came back to Mr Biddle’s and wrote as long as I could hold the pen, but the Summer heat of the day, and the scorching fire of the Sun overpowered me with drowsiness— Mr Kretschmar called upon me, and said he would bring me his translation of my Oration upon La Fayette— I dined with Coll. Drayton and a party. Judge Baldwin, Mr Biddle, Mr Binney, E. S. Burd, D. W. Coxe, Mr Fisher, Judge Hopkinson, Dr Lieber, John Sergeant, Captain Ward, Mr Walsh, and Coll. Drayton’s Son were the company.— We sat late at table—the later for a heavy thunder shower that came up, and as scarcely ever fails in such cases, I talked too much and too dogmatically. Mrs Biddle sent a Carriage for us and we rode home in the rain between nine and ten. Mr Gibbs of Baltimore came in, and Mr Biddle went out with him upon business— I was unable to read, and indifferent company for Mrs Biddle and her Son Charles. I retired before eleven deeply mortified at my own want of discretion, and of modesty.
21. V. Thursday

On taking my box of shaving implements out of my trunk this morning to shave, I found upon opening the box, the looking glass belonging to it broken— This accident never happened to me before— I have had the same box in use in all my travelling for the last eighteen years, and one that preceded it had accompanied me for thirty-four years before. I had a morning visit from Coll. Drayton and Mr Walsh came at eleven and took me out to see two flower-gardens—one belonging to a Frenchman who goes by the name of Smith, who came to it by a marriage with a woman named Mazurois; and the other being the celebrated Bartram Garden, now owned by Coll. Carr, who married a daughter of the last Bartram, and who received us with great civility. The gardens are just now in bloom; and there are multitudes of beautiful flowers. Numbers also of exotic trees, which I had not time to examine. The trade in plants and trees flourishes, and Coll. Carr told me that they now annually had a demand of the them beyond the Alleghany Mountains greater than there was for the whole United States
five years since. The garden is on the banks of the Schuylkill, not half a mile beyond the bridge, and opposite the landing place of the Coal from the mines. Carr said that some days since 123 vessels passed through the draw of the Bridge in one day. I was at this Bridge with the other members of the Bank Committee in April 1832— Three years have since passed away and I should now not have known the place again. A little city of new Streets and houses has on both sides of the Bridge started up as by enchantment— Mr Walsh shewed me a bench under a large tree in the garden looking through a thicket upon a green lawn over the river; upon which bench he said he had made his first proposals of marriage both to his first and to his present wife. On our return to the City he introduced me to her, and to four of his daughters at his own house. Miss Carter a celebrated beauty came in while I was there. We dined at judge Hopkinson’s, with judge Baldwin, Thomas Biddle, D. W. Coxe, Coll. Drayton, Dr. John Hopkinson, Richard Peters, John Sergeant, Dr Chapman, and Mr Scott— Walsh was not there— The company parted about nine.— Mr Biddle gave me Homer’s Edition of Tacitus.
22. V:15. Friday.

I wrote a Letter to my Son Charles to advise him of my being here, and of my hope to reach home this day week, or the day after. Received two Notes from Charles J. Ingersoll—one an invitation to dinner to-morrow— I called at his house but not finding him at home left word that I was engaged for to-morrow, but would call again to see him— Returned H. Binney’s visit, but he was not at home. Called to see Mr Du Ponceau and spent an hour of pleasant conversation with him— He told me of a learned Mexican who had entirely overthrown his system that all the languages of the North American Indians was Polysyllabic, by proving that there is a tribe of Indians in Mexico who speak a monosyllabic language, resembling in many of its characteristic properties, and in multitude of words, the Chinese. Duponceau much to my astonishment had never heard of John Philip Barretier. I read to him part of the Article upon Baratier in Lempriere’s Biographical Dictionary— I visited also Mr Kretschmar the translator of my Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette— I found him keeping a circulating library, and Store of Music and Musical Instruments at N. 70 South third Street— He is a young Westphalian 29 or 30 years of age, who says he has served in the Prussian Artillery six years and has been five years in this Country; preferring a useful occupation in a free country, to military idleness in an absolute monarchy. He says he has succeeded so well in this Country that he expects his father, mother and their family to come over this year to join him and settle in this Country. He sent me his manuscript translation to read. I called upon Mr George Rundle and received 192 dollars for six dividends since April 1832 on the Schuylkill bridge stock. Visited with judge Hopkinson the Academy of fine Arts, and saw the Pictures and Statues.— The only novelty is in the yard, a headless Colossal Statue, said to be of Ceres and near three thousand years old brought by Captain Creighton from Megara.— We dined with John Sergeant, Nicholas and Commodore
James Biddle, Mr Bloodgood of New-York, D. W. Coxe, Elihu Chauncey. Coll. Drayton and his Son, judge Hopkinson, Mr M’Culloh, Mr Wallace, and Coll. Watmough with Mrs. Sergeant and her two eldest daughters were there— W. B. Read came in after dinner— Evening at Captain Read’s. Dominick Lynch and a musical party— Met Mr White of Florida; just arrived, and on his way to New-York to embark for France, to meet and bring back his wife.— Mrs Read, Miss Jones and Miss Garesché sung with Mr Lynch Italian duets with accompaniment of the Piano— Lynch sung also several of Moore’s Melodies; but not with Common Sense one day— His voice and his taste are yet in keeping— The Belle of the company was Elizabeth, daughter of Richard Willing—just sixteen—a child ripening into woman—exquisitely beautiful— Persico was there and said he had a mind to take her bust. At midnight, I forced myself away, leaving most of the company still there.
23. V. Saturday.

Mr Richard Peters and his Son Francis called at ten O’Clock this Morning, and I rode with them, first to the garden and green-house of Mr Henry Pratt, on the banks of the Schuylkill, where were a profusions of flowers in bloom, and a multitude of Plants and trees—with three or four small fish ponds— It is curious only as a garden of Plants, and Mr Pratt, the proprietor keeps it at a very heavy expense, but without ever residing at the place— There were Lemon and Orange-trees in full bearing—and gold and silver fish and tadpoles, embryo frogs in the Ponds.— We then went to Belmont the former Residence of Mr Peters’s father, and where in October 1824. I met and dined with General La Fayette; but the place is now occupied by a farmer and his family, and the mansion is going to decay— The most observable thing left there is the Spring house, where the milk is kept on a brick floor in pans surrounded by the water of a running stream— I took a tumbler full of the milk which was good, but not equal to that of the ruined Castle at Töplitz. We then went to the viaduct across the Schuylkill, and the inclined plane of the Columbia rail-road— It rises 182 feet in a distance of 2840— Several small waggons or cars variously loaded with pine fire-wood, with pine planks, with a small family and their household furniture, were drawn up, or let down upon this plane, while we were there— We returned to the City— I wrote a short Letter to my wife, from whom I had received one this morning— We dined at Dr. Chapman’s. Mr Nicholas Biddle, his brother the Commodore, Thomas Biddle, D. W. Coxe, Judge Hopkinson, Richard Peters, Mr Wharton, and Robert Walsh were the company— Mrs Chapman was at the table. We had conversation, more upon political topics than at any of the preceding parties. Much upon Patronage. The democratic Convention at Baltimore have yesterday nominated unanimously Martin Van Buren, as their Candidate for the Succession to the Presidency, and Richard M Johnson of Kentuckey for Vice-President, by a vote of 185 to 82 for William L Rives of Virginia. There were two delegations from Pennsylvania—one of partizans for the re-election of the present Governor of the State, George Wolff— The other for substituting in his place Henry Muhlenberg the Member of Congress— Both were admitted to vote at the Baltimore Convention, and both voted for Van Buren and Johnson as the National Candidates.— On returning with Mr Biddle to his house this Evening, I received another Letter from my wife—written yesterday.
24. V.30. Sunday.

Mr Fairman came this morning, and I went with him to the Unitarian Church, and heard Dr Channing of Boston, who preached from Matthew 22.36.37. [“]and Jesus said unto him thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy Soul, and with all thy mind” These words he said suggested a great variety of considerations; but he should now confine himself to one, which was that Religion was natural and congenial to the heart of man— That it was peculiar to the constitution of human nature to trace the connection between cause and effect. He enlarged upon this idea with a great variety of illustrations, but without explaining precisely what Jesus meant by the command to his disciples to love God—nor what he himself meant by Religion. His whole discourse impliedly treated the Love of God, and Religion as identical— But his argument left much to question, and much to be explained— The house was crowded almost to suffocation.— After Church we called at Mr Walsh’s, and he engaged me to dine with him— Mr Biddle declined, and rode out of town in the afternoon— I dined with Mr Walsh and his family; his eldest Son, and four elder daughters— Mr Charles Harper of Baltimore, was the only guest except me— There were many visitors after dinner, among whom, Mr John Vaughan, who engaged me to breakfast with him Tuesday morning at half past seven. Mr and Mrs Jaudon with a small boy, were also there, and a young man named Williams, a writer in the American quarterly Review. I took a walk towards Sunset with Mr Walsh, his eldest daughter, and Mr Williams— On returning to Mr Biddle’s at nine, I found a Letter from my wife requiring an immediate answer which I wrote and sent.— I had already received and answered one this morning— My situation is becoming irksome from a conscious feeling of idleness, and of getting to be a burdensome inmate in my friend’s house. I long to be moving homewards, and to return to occupations which may be useful to my family or to myself— I looked this Evening into Henry Lee’s Life of Napoleon, and soon sickened with disgust at what I read. Napoleon was a Harlequin Emperor and King— Lee is a Scaramouch Biographer— I think I shall never read as much more of his book, as I read this Evening.
25. V:30. Monday.

Mr Biddle went out this morning to his Country Seat— I strolled out and returned sundry visits, but found only Coll. Drayton at home— There was something controversial between him and me, when we were members of the Congress before the last, and his attentions to me since I have been now here, have been marked with great civility and kindness. I found at his house as a visitor, General Atkinson of the Army— I concluded to go on to New-York on Thursday, if my wife should not arrive here on Wednesday, and to wait for her there. I wrote to her, to give her the information: finished reading Scribes Comedy of Bertrand et Raton, and made progress in reading the German Translation of the Oration upon La Fayette— I called at the Bank of the United States, and took a draft on the Branch Bank at Boston, for the check of my dividends of the Schuylkill Bridge Stock. Dined at Mr Thomas Biddle’s—my kind host sent by me an excuse—his brother William S. Biddle lying at the point of death with a paralytic disorder. Judge Hopkinson whose
daughter Elizabeth is the wife of William S. Biddle, also sent an excuse— The company at Thomas Biddle’s were E. Chauncey, D. W. Coxe, Coll. Drayton, John Sergeant, J. J. Wallace, Robert Walsh, two Sons of Thomas Biddle, and three or four Strangers with whom I was unacquainted— Coll. Watmough came in after dinner— We sat at table till near nine— Conversation about the times of the Revolution— Much of Charles Thomson, and of John Dickinson— After dinner, I called and passed an hour at Mr Walsh’s with him, and his family—examined a volume of Rezch’s etchings of Shakespear’s Hamlet and Macbeth—Caricatures— Mr Williams came in for News, for to-morrow’s paper—Whig Ministry in England—Berryer’s Speech against the appropriation indemnity Bill in France. I came home at ten, and sat in conversation with Mr and Mrs Biddle, and their eldest Son Edward till near Midnight— The names of their daughters are Meta Adele, and Jane— The younger Son who went on Saturday to Princeton is named Charles. Mr. Thomas Biddle’s wife was a daughter of Jonathan Williams—a portrait of whom; a strong likeness was suspended in his dining-room.

26. V. Tuesday.— Breakfasted—with Mr John Vaughan, at his chambers at the Athenaeum. The Building where the Meetings of the American Philosophical Society are held. Dr. Julius the Commissioner from Prussia, for Enquiries about education and Penitentiaries. Coll. Drayton, Dr. Channing, Mr Furness, and Mr William Ware of New-York were there— The conversation was miscellaneous Dr Julius left the company to proceed by the ten O’Clock boat for New York— Mr. Vaughan shewed us the manuscript papers of Arthur Lee, given to the Society by his nephew and biographer Richard Henry Lee— Sometime after the breakfast was over, Mr Duponceau and Mr Gallatin came in, the last from New-York last Evening— About eleven I returned to Mr Biddle’s; received and answered a Letter from B. F. Hallett of Boston; and read nearly through, my Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette, in the German Translation of Mr Kratschmar. Dined at Coll. Watmough’s—Mr Thomas Biddle, E. F. Chambers, E. Chauncey, Mr Jaudon, John Sergeant, and Mr Waggaman, late Senator from Louisiana, with Mrs Watmough constituted the company— After dinner I called upon Mr John Connell, and came home again about ten in the Evening; found visitors, young Biddle’s, with the family— There was great Sensation in public this day, occasioned by the intelligence arrived of the passage by the French House of deputies of the Bill of Appropriation of indemnities by a very large majority, with a condition annexed however that no part of the money shall be paid, till the French Government shall have received satisfactory explanations, concerning the Message of the President of the United States of the 2d. of December 1834 to Congress— The majority for the Bill is totally unexpected, and the Appropriation includes interest from the time when the payments should have been made— The demand for explanations, throws an aukward obstacle in the way of a final Settlement, but otherwise the victory of President Jackson’s Administration, is complete; and will sweep away every fragment of opposition to the remainder of his term— His experiment was a hazardous one, and the management of the Negotiation by his Cabinet has exhibited great maladdress— The opposition to his measures has however been much more blundering, and has proved excessively unpopular— It forgot the question, in which the interest of the Country was involved— May that ultimately prevail, by obtaining the full measure of Justice, required for the Satisfaction of its rights.
27. V. Wednesday.

I went this morning to Head’s Mansion-house, to Congress-Hall and to the Tremont House to engage lodgings for myself and my family, and found we could be accommodated only at Congress Hall. I returned the German Translation of the Oration upon La Fayette to Mr Kretschmar, and pointed out to him several passages where I thought there were mistakes. I went then with Mr Biddle and Mr Hemphill and visited the House of refuge or poor-house of the City: a new, yet unfinished establishment of four large buildings in parallelogram, forming a hollow square, beyond, South and West of the Schuylkill. From twelve to eighteen hundred paupers, male and female, black and white, adults and children are here maintained—among them from three to four hundred Lunatics, and insane. The Directors were to have this day a turtle feast at the house— Thence I went with Mr Biddle to the Penitentiary—where I saw my old acquaintance Napier the Burglar, and three Counterfeitors, Charley Mitchell, Lyman Parks of Russell, Hambden County, Massachusetts, and Adams a Connecticut man— Napier recognized me— He is in bad health, and so are all the others— We went to Chesnut Street wharf at the moment when the Steamer Constitution arrived from Newcastle, but my wife and the children were not in the Boat. I dined at Mr Jaudon’s with Mr Carneal, John Connell, Coll. Drayton, Dr Harris, Mr Humphreys, Mr Norris, Richard Peters, Mr Waggaman, Robert Walsh junr. and Coll Watmough— Mrs Jaudon was at the table. Four children, two Sons and two daughters came in after dinner— In the Evening I went with Mr Peters and Mr Waggaman to the Walnut Street theatre, and saw Cooper and his daughter perform Benedick and Beatrice, in Much Ado about Nothing— It was a Benefit Play for Miss Cooper, a young debutante who has merit. Cooper himself has a remnant of power—but I saw him in Othello in 1802—then in his prime.— I met Charles J. Ingersoll at the theatre. Mr Peters and Mr Waggaman came home with me. I then received a Letter from my wife, written yesterday, and expect her with the family by the Boat to-morrow. I have concluded to wait for them, instead of proceeding by the ten O’Clock Boat, for New-York.
28. V:30. Thursday.

My visit of Friendship and Pleasure to Philadelphia, probably the last that I shall have the opportunity of paying, is closed— Mr Biddle went with me again this morning to the Mansion house, Head’s, to enquire for lodgings for my family, but they had no room— We there met Mr James Sheridan Knowles, who thanked me for my verses in his Album, to Miss Elphinstone, written on the 3d. of March. I then called at Yohe’s, the American Hotel, but there were no convenient apartments to be obtained there; and I engaged them finally at Congress Hall—Wells’s— Mr Biddle went with me also to the grave-yard of St. Peter’s Church, where I saw the monument erected by the friends of Joseph Dennie to his Memory in 1819—the obituary inscription upon which was written by me— I returned sundry visits which I had until this day neglected— To E. S. Burd, D. W. Coxe, Elihu Chauncey and to John J. Wallace, who received me. I called besides on Luigi Persico, and on Mrs Roberdeau, whom I saw, and her daughter Susan. Mr M’Kean Buchanan had visited me this morning. He has recently returned with his
wife from his visit to the Island of Cuba, with his health entirely restored— At two O’Clock I dined in family with Mr Biddle, and he accompanied me at 3. to the Chesnut Street wharf, where my family had all been a full half hour arrived— My wife, Mary, her two children, Mary-Louisa, and Georgiana-Frances, John Wilson and his wife, Catherine Good, and Rachel Thomas, the black woman Cook— They were all taken to Congress Hall, where they dined, and we took lodgings for the Night— They left Washington yesterday at 2 O’Clock P.M and my wife and Mary wish to proceed as rapidly as possible upon the Journey— After they had dined I returned to Mr Biddle’s where I took leave of him and his family, with whom I have spent ten days, entertained with the kindest hospitality— I sent my baggage to Congress Hall, and at the dusk of Evening joined my family there— Mr Biddle accompanied me to the door of the House— Commodore James Biddle was at his house when I left it— I had in the morning called at the House of Mr Walsh; he was not there—but I saw his Son, and returned to him the Comedy of Bertrand et Raton.

div.p: 29. IV:45. Friday— From Philadelphia to New-York; and Steamer President, Long-Island Sound.

At six O’Clock this morning we embarked in the Steamboat at Philadelphia, and at a quarter before nine, landed at Bordentown, where the Railway Cars took us up— The family occupying one division of a Car— At half past eleven we reached Amboy, and there entered the other Steamer which landed us at New-York, at five minutes before two. At an adjoining wharf lay the Steamboat President, Captain E. S. Bunker, and without waiting to pass a Night in New-York, we only passed from one boat to the other— I took a walk into Broad way, and viewed the walls of the large Hotel, of Quincy Granite, which Mr John Jacob Astor is building; the walls of which are now at the fifth Story— I met in the Street Mr Richard H. Wilde, late a member of the House of Representatives of the United States from Georgia, who is going to England. On the passage from Philadelphia to New-York, I met with no old acquaintance—but a Mr Hart, who landed at Burlington, a Mr Harris who landed at Elizabethtown, and a Mr Hotchkiss of New-Haven, accosted me as having seen me before, and had each some conversation with me. In the Steamboat President I met Mr Potts the member of Congress from Pennsylvania, the Revd. Doctor Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright of Boston, and Mr Joseph Tilden— Dr Wainwright’s father was also at the boat to take leave of his Son; with whom he has been spending the Winter at Boston. He is now upon his return to England, where he resides at twelve miles distance from Liverpool—going in the Packet, to sail on the first of next month— I think I had not seen him, since I dined with him at his house in Cambridge, in July 1809— His Son was then about closing the term of his Freshman year at the University— His wife, my mother and brother were all at that dinner— It was the day, on which I delivered the last of my Lectures on Rhetoric and Oratory— What changes and Revolutions since that day! Twenty-six years of interval have added furrows to his brows and to mine— We now met and parted with much cordiality. At 5 O’Clock the boat left the wharf, with fair weather and a gentle breeze, and before dark were in Long Island Sound, our Boat’s motion being much retarded— One of her engines is out of order so that it cannot be worked— In the course of the Evening, I had various conversation, with Mr Potts, Mr Tilden, and Dr Wainwright, till between ten and eleven O’Clock when I retired to my State room to bed. I bought a shaving-brush at New-York for a reminiscence.
30. V:15. Saturday.— From off Block Island to Providence and Quincy.

The night was fine, and the water smooth— The Steamer limped along at the rate of ten miles an hour, and on rising this morning, after a night of sound Sleep, very unusual for me in a Steamboat, I found her opposite Block Island, with a heavy swell, though with a calm Sea. Most of the Lady and children Passengers, and some of the men were sick—we came round point Judith about eight O’Clock; passed the Newport Light House at nine—landed the Newport Passengers at about 1/2 past nine—took in Mr Nathaniel Amory who resides at Newport, but was going to Boston—and landed at Providence at Noon, just in time to see the other Steamer depart for New-York— I wrote a few lines to my Son Charles to inform him that we hoped to reach Quincy this Evening, and gave them to Dr. Wainwright who promised to send them immediately after his arrival at Boston— I took at Providence a whole Stage for my own family to bring us immediately to Quincy. At half past twelve we left Providence— At a quarter before four, dined at Mrs Fuller’s at Walpole— Fuller himself died the 22d. of May 1833— We turned off from the Boston road at Dedham, and reached our own home at Quincy, at seven in the Evening, a quarter of an hour before Sunset. My Son Charles had arrived there not five minutes before us; having received my note by Dr Wainwright just in time to come out and meet us. He was in good health and Spirits; his wife having presented him with a second Son, last Wednesday the 27th. He returned to Boston this Evening; promising to come out again to-morrow. The weather was rather warm, and I closed the day with a grateful heart for the blessing of our safe arrival, all well; from this long journey of 500 miles— The Country all the way from Providence is in full bloom— The Apple Orchards loaded with blossoms— The Lilacs and Horse Chesnuts charming the eye, and filling the atmosphere with fragrance. The nests of Caterpillars swarming in the Orchards give testimony that the reproduction of animal life keeps pace with that of vegetation.
31. V. Sunday

Mr Beale called on me this morning and I went with him to meeting and heard Mr Farley of Providence, preach from Leviticus 19.32. “Thou shalt rise up before the hoary head, and honour the face of the old man, and fear thy God: I am the Lord.”— Mr Farley was eloquent upon the reverence due to old age; and marked it as a peculiar excellence of the Law delivered from Sinai that it was enjoined with so much solemnity: coupled in the text with the fear of God; and closing thus with the emphatic observation—I am the Lord. The afternoon Sermon was by Mr Huntoon of Milton, from Hebrews 6.1. “Therefore leaving the principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on unto perfection.”— The Christian obligation of aiming at perfection, is one of the great superiorities of the gospel over all other systems of religion: for, frail and inconsistent beings as we are, if we are sincere in the belief of the obligation of our religious duties, we must be improved by the constant conviction that it is our duty to aim at perfection— Mr Whitney gave notice that the first bell, on Wednesday
next for the installation of Mr Lunt would ring at ten O’Clock, and the second at eleven— He also gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday. I read the ninth Sermon of the sixth Volume of Saurin, upon true Liberty.— The subject is not treated as it would be at this time. Saurin considers the Liberty mentioned in his text as the liberation of men by Jesus Christ from the Laws of the Mosaic dispensation—and Liberty as regarding 1. The understanding 2. the will 3. the conscience 4. the conduct 5. the condition of man— Charles came out from Boston this afternoon with Mrs Kirk: he was here about an hour and returned to Boston— I looked into my garden this morning, and found it as usual overrun with weeds— Many of my trees killed—the seedling trees of former years looking for the most part unpromisingly, and a small portion of the seeds that I planted last Summer and autumn coming up— While I was in the garden Mr E. Price Greenleaf came, and advised me to leave the weeds growing, to protect the nascent Seedlings from the Sun—
